column18: 01/23/2002: The Odessa city prosecutor, Halyna Klymovych, was the target of a car-bombing in Odessa, Ukraine. The prosecutor was unhurt in the attack, although two others were injured.
column97: The car bomb was suspected to be detonated via remote control. Nails and army explosives had been placed under the car.
column125: The main theory investigated in regard to the cause of the assassination attempt was that it was an attempt to frighten or kill Halyna Klymovych, who had investigated several major criminal cases in Odessa.
column126: �Car bomb explodes in front of prosecutor�s apartment,� Novyy Kanal Television, January 23, 2002.

column18: 3/29/2002: Mykola Shkriblyak, a candidate of the Social Democratic Party, was shot inside of his apartment building in Kiev, Kiev City Municipality, Ukraine.  He died the next day from his injuries.  No group has claimed responsibility for the attack and the motive is unknown; however, the attack occurred two days before parliamentary elections.
column39: Mykola Shkriblyak, a candidate of the Social Democratic Party
column64: Specific motive is unknown; however, officials speculate that it was meant to intimidate Shkriblyak's colleagues.
column97: He was shot from behind by an unknown gunman
column131: 2002.\",\"\"\"Parliamentary hopeful shot dead in western Ukraine"
column134: 2002.\",\"\"\"Candidate murdered days before Ukraine's parliamentary elections"

column18: 05/11/2002: An unknown perpetrator threw two gasoline bombs at the house of a Ukrainian journalist who worked for Fest and for Staryy Zamok regional newspapers in Berehove, Ukraine. The bombs started a fire that was extinguished before anyone was hurt. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
column38: Fest and Staryy Zamok Regional Newspapers
column97: Two gasoline bombs were thrown at the house.
column126: �Arson attack on journalist's house reported in western Ukraine,� Interfax, May 11, 2002.

column18: 11/19/2003: Five unknown attackers severely beat Oleksandr Levit, a reporter for the Ukrainian newspaper Fakty I Kommentarii, in Odessa, Ukraine.  The attackers indicated that the beating was a response to the journalist�s critical articles.  No group claimed responsibility for the assault.
column39: Oleksandr Levit, a reporter working for the Fakty I Kommentarii Newspaper in Odessa
column64: The attack was a response to the victim's critical reporting of the perpetrator's group.
column125: Fakty I Kommentarii did not believe that Levit's reporting had motivated the attack against him.
column126: �Ukraine Journalist Receives Beating in Odessa,� Interfax, November 20, 2003.
column127: �Ukrainian Journalist Beaten in Latest Attack,� The Associated Press, November 20, 2003.

column18: 11/07/2007: Unknown attackers released tear gas into a Russian-language school in Lviv, Ukraine. The school was evacuated and no one was injured. There were no media accounts of any group claiming responsibility for the attack.
column64: Police suspected that it was a culturally-related attack - Russian symbols have been a target of vandalism.

column17: Shevchenko Park in Kyiv, Ukraine, Ukraine.
column18: 4/21/2008: On Monday, at 1910, an unidentified explosive device equivalent to some 100 grams of TNT went off in Shevchenko Park in Kyiv, Ukraine, Ukraine. The blast wounded two female students from the Taras Shevchenko National University, who were passing by at the moment of the explosion. The attack could have been a terrorist attack marking Adolf Hitler's birthday. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
column39: Two female students from the Taras Shevchenko National University
column64: The attack could have been a terrorist attack marking Adolf Hitler's birthday.
column97: An unidentified explosive device equivalent to some 100 grams of TNT.
column127: \"\"Blast in Kyiv Park Could Have Been Committed to Mark Hitler's Birthday - Interior Minister"
column131: \"\"Blast in Kyiv Park Could Have Been Committed to Mark Hitler's Birthday -  Interior Minister"

column18: 07/08/1999: Two unknown assailants lobbed two Molotov cocktails at the United States Embassy in Kiev, Ukraine. The fire was immediately extinguished and there were no injuries or damage to the area.

column18: 11/07/1999: The apartment of an ethnic Russian, Tetiana Shvetsova, in the city of Lviv, Ukraine, was set ablaze by unknown extremists. This is one of three attacks on three separate apartments owned by ethnic Russians or Jews in Lviv on 11/07/1999. No casualties resulted from the incident. It was unknown who was responsible for the incident.
column97: There was no report describing how the arson was set.
column125: This is one of 3 related incidents (cf. 199911070007, 199911070008). Tetiana Shvetsova head an ethnic Russian womens' group in western Ukraine.
column126: �Apartments of Jewish, ethnic Russian leaders torched in western Ukraine,� Associated Press Worldstream, November 16, 1999.

column18: 11/07/1999: The apartment of an ethnic Jew, Professor Rudolf Myrsky, in the city of Lviv, Ukraine, was set ablaze by unknown extremists. This is one of three attacks on three separate apartments owned by ethnic Russians or Jews in Lviv on 11/07/1999. No casualties resulted from the incident. It was unknown who was responsible for the incident.
column97: There was no report describing how the arson was set.
column125: This is one of 3 related incidents (cf. 199911070006, 199911070008). Professor Rudolf Myrsky was a member of the Golden Rose Jewish association.
column126: �Apartments of Jewish, ethnic Russian leaders torched in western Ukraine,� Associated Press Worldstream, November 16, 1999.

This is one of three attacks on three separate apartments owned by ethnic Russians or Jews in Lviv on 11/07/1999. No casualties resulted from the incident. It was unknown who was responsible for the incident.
column97: There was no report describing how the arson was set.

column18: 11/23/1999: Unidentified assailants attempted to assassinate Dmitri Divorces of the Vinnitsa Regional Administration in Kiev, Ukraine. Dvorkis and his bodyguard were wounded and his driver was killed.

column18: 11/7/2000: An unidentified individual placed a bomb at the First Ukrainian International Bank in Luhansk, Luhansk Oblast, Ukraine.  No one was injured in the explosion and the building suffered only minor damage.  No group claimed responsibility for the attack and the motive is unknown.
